pullRequest.title: New sample: Animate images image overlay
pullRequest.bodyText: I'm assuming by the time this gets through review etc that this will be going into the new release master, so that's why I chose master branch rather than dev. @JonLavi would you be able to take a first review please when you have a moment? this is my first Java sample in a while...hope I haven't missed anything too obvious off!

commit.message: get the scene view and initial starting position in place
get image frame set up for each png file
set up logic for image overlay opacity change
handle timer for displaying image frames
wire up combobox to timer to change speed

nodes.bodyText: I think we recently discussed naming this "Animate images with image overlays" so that it reads a bit smoother. Let's refer back to the common repo and see whether that change was made official.
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,37 @@
+# Animate images with image overlay

nodes.bodyText: Perhaps we can just remove this first sentence? It's more general info / about the data rather than how to use the sample.
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,37 @@
+# Animate images with image overlay
+
+Animate a series of images with an image overlay.
+
+![Image of animate images with image overlay](AnimateImagesWithImageOverlay.gif)
+
+## Use case
+
+An image overlay is useful for displaying fast and dynamic images; for example, rendering real-time sensor data captured from a drone. Each frame from the drone becomes a static image which is updated on the fly as the data is made available.
+
+## How to use the sample
+
+The application loads a map of the Southwestern United States. Click the "Start/Stop" button to start or stop the radar animation. Use the drop down menu to select how quickly the animation plays. Move the slider to change the opacity of the image overlay.

nodes.bodyText:
Perhaps we can rephrase this sentence so that it's not so perscriptive, so that we don't accidentally imply that 15fps is the only way to do it? e.g.
Set up a timer with your desired interval time. For example, an interval of 67ms is roughly equivalent to  15 fps.
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,37 @@
+# Animate images with image overlay
+
+Animate a series of images with an image overlay.
+
+![Image of animate images with image overlay](AnimateImagesWithImageOverlay.gif)
+
+## Use case
+
+An image overlay is useful for displaying fast and dynamic images; for example, rendering real-time sensor data captured from a drone. Each frame from the drone becomes a static image which is updated on the fly as the data is made available.
+
+## How to use the sample
+
+The application loads a map of the Southwestern United States. Click the "Start/Stop" button to start or stop the radar animation. Use the drop down menu to select how quickly the animation plays. Move the slider to change the opacity of the image overlay.
+
+## How it works
+
+1. Create an `ImageOverlay` and add it to the `SceneView`.
+2. Set up a timer with an initial interval time of 67ms, equivalent to ~15fps.

nodes.bodyText:
Perhaps we should add some information here on there being two ways of creating an ImageOverlay:
From a URL and from a JavaFX Image. For the latter, TIFF is not supported
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,37 @@
+# Animate images with image overlay
+
+Animate a series of images with an image overlay.
+
+![Image of animate images with image overlay](AnimateImagesWithImageOverlay.gif)
+
+## Use case
+
+An image overlay is useful for displaying fast and dynamic images; for example, rendering real-time sensor data captured from a drone. Each frame from the drone becomes a static image which is updated on the fly as the data is made available.
+
+## How to use the sample
+
+The application loads a map of the Southwestern United States. Click the "Start/Stop" button to start or stop the radar animation. Use the drop down menu to select how quickly the animation plays. Move the slider to change the opacity of the image overlay.
+
+## How it works
+
+1. Create an `ImageOverlay` and add it to the `SceneView`.
+2. Set up a timer with an initial interval time of 67ms, equivalent to ~15fps.
+3. For every image, create a new `ImageFrame` and add it to the image overlay at evern timer interval.
+
+## Relevant API
+
+* ImageFrame
+* ImageOverlay
+* SceneView
+
+## About the data
+
+These radar images were captured by the US National Weather Service (NWS). They highlight the Pacific Southwest sector which is made up of part the western United States and Mexico. For more information visit the [National Weather Service](https://www.weather.gov/jetstream/gis) website.
+
+## Additional information
+
+The supported image formats are GeoTIFF, TIFF, JPEG, and PNG. `ImageOverlay` does not support the rich processing and rendering capabilities of a `RasterLayer`. Use `Raster` and `RasterLayer` for static image rendering, analysis, and persistence.

nodes.bodyText: Perhaps we should take the drone keyword out. It's a very specific use case, but there's no direct relevance to the API
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,37 @@
+# Animate images with image overlay
+
+Animate a series of images with an image overlay.
+
+![Image of animate images with image overlay](AnimateImagesWithImageOverlay.gif)
+
+## Use case
+
+An image overlay is useful for displaying fast and dynamic images; for example, rendering real-time sensor data captured from a drone. Each frame from the drone becomes a static image which is updated on the fly as the data is made available.
+
+## How to use the sample
+
+The application loads a map of the Southwestern United States. Click the "Start/Stop" button to start or stop the radar animation. Use the drop down menu to select how quickly the animation plays. Move the slider to change the opacity of the image overlay.
+
+## How it works
+
+1. Create an `ImageOverlay` and add it to the `SceneView`.
+2. Set up a timer with an initial interval time of 67ms, equivalent to ~15fps.
+3. For every image, create a new `ImageFrame` and add it to the image overlay at evern timer interval.
+
+## Relevant API
+
+* ImageFrame
+* ImageOverlay
+* SceneView
+
+## About the data
+
+These radar images were captured by the US National Weather Service (NWS). They highlight the Pacific Southwest sector which is made up of part the western United States and Mexico. For more information visit the [National Weather Service](https://www.weather.gov/jetstream/gis) website.
+
+## Additional information
+
+The supported image formats are GeoTIFF, TIFF, JPEG, and PNG. `ImageOverlay` does not support the rich processing and rendering capabilities of a `RasterLayer`. Use `Raster` and `RasterLayer` for static image rendering, analysis, and persistence.
+
+## Tags
+
+3D, animation, drone, dynamic, image frame, image overlay, real time, rendering

nodes.bodyText: I think we're supposed to leave this entry out of the README.metadata.json, but I'm not sure any more. @mikewilburn, could you refresh our memories please?

nodes.bodyText:
I'm not 100% sure any more, but I think the standard order for the imports is:
java.*
<newline>
javafx.*
<newline>
com.esri.*
We might not need this as a member variable, could just make it a var inside addNextImageFrameToImageOverlay?

I think the samples convention was not to instantiate class members when we declare them, but do either in the main method, with a comment about what they are for, or ideally  just before you use them. I don't actually mind them being instantiated here, but best check what the common pattern is.
Can we just define an envelope straight away with four corner points, instead of Evelope(center, width, height)?
There's only one ImageOverlay being used in this sample, so we can make it a class member instead of repeating sceneView.getImageOverlays().get(0) here and below?

This is UI stuff so perhaps it's better to do it before we get to setting up the Scene/SceneView. It might be even possible to define all these things in the FXML file, might be worth having a look?
I also think it's counterintuitive to have the high values at the top rather than the bottom.
This method is being called at the end of initialize so maybe we can put it directly after initialize, that way we're not making readers scroll past the two other methods first.
It might also make more sense to call it 'frameIndex', since we use it to pick an entry from List<ImageFrame> imageFrames, not from imageFiles[]

Suggested change
        
          
    

        
      
    
    
      
          
            
               * Create a new image frame from the image at the current index and add it to the image overlay.
          
          
            
               * Sets the next image frame from the array of image frames to the image overlay.

If you wanted, you could add Key-Value pairs of String-Int to the ComboBox, and use a cell factory to display the key (15/30/60 fps), and then on selection just put in the corresponding value (17/33/67) straight into the startNewAnimationTimer. Let me know if you want me to walk you through it.
GitHub is conveniently letting us know there's a newline missing here 😄

+    
+</StackPane>

commit.message: update method name and make imageoverlay class variable
move fxml style logic to css
move combobox logic, update JavaDoc and move timer method up

nodes.bodyText:
Just found a couple of resource for CSS in fxml:
https://docs.oracle.com/javafx/2/layout/style_css.htm
https://docs.oracle.com/javafx/2/api/javafx/scene/doc-files/cssref.html#gridpane
You could get rid of the rules here by adding to the css:
Grid Pane {
	-fx-max-width: 500;
    -fx-hgap: 30;
    -fx-vgap: 10;
}

It looks like we could get away with removing the styleClass="stack-pane" and styleClass="panel-region" (there's no other stack-pane that we need to differentiate that one from in the fxml file). Might be worth trying to remove them and see how the CSS reacts.
I think moving the 'min/maxWidth' parameters to the CSS is definitely ok, it's more cosmetic rather than any direct relevance to the code. I think it'd be good to highlight the fx:id parts and the method calls (onAction="#handleframesComboBoxInteraction"), so let's bring those to the front of the node declarations.
Looks like you can also define the alignment within the StackPane in the CSS file:
https://docs.oracle.com/javafx/2/api/javafx/scene/doc-files/cssref.html#stackpane
You could even declare most of the params for the slider:
https://docs.oracle.com/javafx/2/api/javafx/scene/doc-files/cssref.html#slider
only thing I can't see in there is whether we can control the element's position inside the grid pane (i.e. replace GridPane.rowIndex="0" etc.)
I'll let you decide when too much is too much 😄

nodes.bodyText: @Rachael-E regarding the performance aspect of this, have you tried holding on to an ArrayList<Image> and creating the ImageFrame ad-hoc, only when it needs to be displayed? There seems to be quite a difference in memory consumption between a collection of Image and ImageFrame, as other platforms are reporting

Suggested change
        
          
    

        
      
    
    
      
          
            
                "title": "Animate Images With Image Overlay"
          
          
            
                "title": "Animate Images with Image Overlay"

nodes.bodyText: Should also handle the case of missing data with an alert.
I'm surprised this can't be done with just frameIndex++. The modulo operation looks a bit funky 😄
We're technically now using the Timeline class so may need to find better wording for this?

commit.message: update css and fxml for sample viewer rendering
add additional directory for images to go in for sample viewer
